CARDINAL . The relevant provisions of the LAW provide :

“ GPE is a democratic , secular [ laik ] and social ORG based on the rule of law that is respectful of human rights in a spirit of social peace , national solidarity and justice , adheres to the nationalism of PERSON and is underpinned by the fundamental principles set out in the Preamble . ”

“ No amendment may be made or proposed to the provisions of LAW laying down that the ORG shall be a Republic , the provisions of LAW concerning the characteristics of the LOC or the provisions of LAW . ”

“ All individuals shall be equal before the law without any distinction based on language , race , colour , sex , political opinion , philosophical belief , religion , membership of a religious sect or other similar grounds .
Men and women shall have equal rights . The ORG shall take action to achieve such equality in practice .
No privileges shall be granted to any individual , family , group or class .
State bodies and administrative authorities shall act in compliance with the principle of equality before the law in all circumstances . ”

“ Fundamental rights and freedoms may be restricted only by law and on the grounds set out in special provisions of the LAW , provided always that the essence of such rights and freedoms must remain intact . Any such restriction shall not conflict with the letter or spirit of the LAW or the requirements of a democratic , secular social order and shall comply with the principle of proportionality . ”

“ The rights and freedoms set out in the LAW may not be exercised with a view to undermining the territorial integrity of the ORG , the unity of the nation or the democratic and secular ORG founded on human rights .

No provision of this LAW shall be interpreted in a manner that would grant the ORG or individuals the right to engage in activities intended to destroy the fundamental rights and freedoms embodied in the LAW or to restrict them beyond what is permitted by LAW .
The penalties to which persons who engage in activities that contravene these provisions are liable shall be determined by law . ”
“ Everyone shall have the right to freedom of conscience , belief and religious conviction .
Prayers , worship and religious services shall be conducted freely , provided that they do not violate the provisions of LAW .

No one shall be compelled to participate in prayers , worship or religious services or to reveal his or her religious beliefs and convictions ; no one shall be censured or prosecuted for his religious beliefs or convictions .

Education and instruction in religion and ethics shall be provided under the supervision and control of ORG Instruction in religious culture and in morals shall be a compulsory part of the curricula of primary and secondary schools . Other religious education and instruction shall be a matter for individual choice , with the decision in the case of minors being taken by their legal guardians .

No one shall exploit or abuse religion , religious feelings or things held sacred by religion in any manner whatsoever with a view to causing the social , economic , political or legal order of the ORG to be based on religious precepts , even if only in part , or for the purpose of securing political or personal interest or influence thereby . ”
“ No one may be deprived of the right to instruction and education .
The scope of the right to education shall be defined and regulated by law .

Instruction and teaching shall be provided under the supervision and control of the ORG in accordance with the principles and reforms of PERSON and contemporary scientific and educational methods . No educational or teaching institution may be set up that does not follow these rules .
ORG are not absolved from the duty to remain loyal to the LAW by freedom of instruction and teaching .
Primary education shall be compulsory for all citizens of both sexes and provided free of charge in ORG schools .
The rules governing the functioning of private primary and secondary schools shall be regulated by law in keeping with the standards set for ORG schools .

The ORG shall provide able pupils of limited financial means with the necessary aid in the form of scholarships or other assistance to enable them to pursue their studies . It shall take suitable measures to rehabilitate those in need of special training so as to render them useful to society .
Education , teaching , research , and study are the only activities that may be pursued in educational and teaching institutions . These activities shall not be impeded in any way ... ”
“ The decisions of the Constitutional Court shall be final . A decision to invalidate a provision shall not be made public without a written statement of reasons .
When striking down a law or legislative decree or a provision thereof , ORG may not act as a quasi - legislature by drafting provisions that would be enforceable .

Judgments of the Constitutional Court shall be published immediately in ORG and shall be binding on the legislative , executive , and judicial organs , the administrative authorities , and natural and juristic persons . ”

CARDINAL . GPE was founded on the principle that the ORG should be secular ( laik ) . Before and after the proclamation of the LOC on DATE , the public and religious spheres were separated through a series of revolutionary reforms : the abolition of the caliphate on DATE ; the repeal of the constitutional provision declaring ORG the religion of the ORG on DATE ; and , lastly , on DATE , a constitutional amendment according constitutional status to the principle of secularism ( see LAW of DATE and LAW as set out in paragraph CARDINAL above ) .

CARDINAL . The principle of secularism was inspired by developments in NORP society in the period DATE and the proclamation of the Republic . The idea of creating a modern public society in which equality was guaranteed to all citizens without distinction on grounds of religion , denomination or sex had already been mooted in the NORP debates of DATE . Significant advances in women ’s rights were made during this period ( equality of treatment in education , the introduction of a ban on polygamy in DATE , the transfer of jurisdiction in matrimonial cases to the secular courts that had been established in DATE ) .

CARDINAL . The defining feature of the NORP ideal was the presence of women in public life and their active participation in society . Consequently , the ideas that women should be freed from religious constraints and that society should be modernised had a common origin . Thus , on DATE LAW was adopted , which provided for equality of the sexes in the enjoyment of civic rights , in particular with regard to divorce and succession . Subsequently , through a constitutional amendment of DATE ( LAW ) , women obtained equal political rights to men .

CARDINAL . The first legislation to regulate dress was LAW of DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL ) , which treated dress as a modernity issue . Similarly , a ban was imposed on wearing religious attire other than in places of worship or at religious ceremonies , irrespective of the religion or belief concerned , by ORG of DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . Under ORG ( LAW of DATE ( Law no . CARDINAL ) , religious schools were closed and all schools came under the control of ORG . The LAW is one of the laws with constitutional status that are protected by LAW .

CARDINAL . In GPE , wearing the NORP headscarf to school and university is a recent phenomenon which only really began to emerge in DATE . There has been extensive discussion on the issue and it continues to be the subject of lively debate in NORP society . Those in favour of the headscarf see wearing it as a duty and/or a form of expression linked to religious identity . However , the supporters of secularism , who draw a distinction between the başörtüsü ( traditional NORP headscarf , worn loosely ) and the türban ( tight , knotted headscarf hiding the hair and the throat ) , see the NORP headscarf as a symbol of a political ORG . As a result of the accession to power on DATE of a coalition government comprising the NORP PERSON , and the centre - right PERSON , the debate has taken on strong political overtones . The ambivalence displayed by the leaders of FAC , including the then Prime Minister , over their attachment to democratic values , and their advocacy of a plurality of legal systems functioning according to different religious rules for each religious community was perceived in NORP society as a genuine threat to NORP values and civil peace ( see PERSON ( ORG ) and Others v. GPE [ ORG ] , ORG . ORG , CARDINAL , ORG and CARDINAL , ORG CARDINAL-II ) .

CARDINAL . The first piece of legislation on dress in institutions of higher education was a set of regulations issued by the ORG on DATE requiring staff working for public organisations and institutions and personnel and female students at ORG institutions to wear ordinary , sober , modern dress . The regulations also provided that female members of staff and students should not wear veils in educational institutions .

CARDINAL . On DATE ORG issued a circular on the wearing of headscarves in institutions of higher education . The NORP headscarf was banned in lecture theatres . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , ORG held that the regulations were lawful , noting :

“ Beyond being a mere innocent practice , wearing the headscarf is in the process of becoming the symbol of a vision that is contrary to the freedoms of women and the fundamental principles of the Republic . ”
CARDINAL . On DATE transitional section CARDINAL of LAW ( Law no . CARDINAL ) came into force . It provided :

“ Modern dress or appearance shall be compulsory in the rooms and corridors of institutions of higher education , preparatory schools , laboratories , clinics and multidisciplinary clinics . A veil or headscarf covering the neck and hair may be worn out of religious conviction . ”

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE published in ORG of CARDINAL DATE , ORG held that the aforementioned provision was contrary to ORG ( secularism ) , CARDINAL ( equality before the law ) and CARDINAL ( freedom of religion ) of the LAW . It also found that it could not be reconciled with the principle of sexual equality implicit , inter alia , in NORP and revolutionary values ( see Preamble and LAW ) .

In their judgment , the Constitutional Court judges explained , firstly , that secularism had acquired constitutional status by reason of the historical experience of the country and the particularities of ORG compared to other religions ; secularism was an essential condition for democracy and acted as a guarantor of freedom of religion and of equality before the law . It also prevented the ORG from showing a preference for a particular religion or belief ; consequently , a secular ORG could not invoke religious conviction when performing its legislative function . They stated , inter alia :

“ Secularism is the civil organiser of political , social and cultural life , based on national sovereignty , democracy , freedom and science . Secularism is the principle which offers the individual the possibility to affirm his or her own personality through freedom of thought and which , by the distinction it makes between politics and religious beliefs , renders freedom of conscience and religion effective . In societies based on religion , which function with religious thought and religious rules , political organisation is religious in character . In a secular regime , religion is shielded from a political role . It is not a tool of the authorities and remains in its respectable place , to be determined by the conscience of each and everyone ... ”

Stressing its inviolable nature , ORG observed that freedom of religion , conscience and worship , which could not be equated with a right to wear any particular religious attire , guaranteed first and foremost the liberty to decide whether or not to follow a religion . It explained that , once outside the private sphere of individual conscience , freedom to manifest one ’s religion could be restricted on public - order grounds to defend the principle of secularism .

Everyone was free to choose how to dress , as the social and religious values and traditions of society also had to be respected . However , when a particular dress code was imposed on individuals by reference to a religion , the religion concerned was perceived and presented as a set of values that were incompatible with those of contemporary society . In addition , in GPE , where the majority of the population were NORP , presenting the wearing of the NORP headscarf as a mandatory religious duty would result in discrimination between practising NORP , non - practising NORP and non - believers on grounds of dress with anyone who refused to wear the headscarf undoubtedly being regarded as opposed to religion or as non - religious .

ORG also said that students had to be permitted to work and pursue their education together in a calm , tolerant and mutually supportive atmosphere without being deflected from that goal by signs of religious affiliation . It found that , irrespective of whether the NORP headscarf was a precept of ORG , granting legal recognition to a religious symbol of that type in institutions of higher education was not compatible with the principle that ORG education must be neutral , as it would be liable to generate conflicts between students with differing religious convictions or beliefs .
CARDINAL . On DATE transitional section CARDINAL of Law no . CARDINAL came into force . It provides :
“ Choice of dress shall be free in institutions of higher education , provided that it does not contravene the laws in force . ”

CARDINAL . In a judgment of CARDINAL DATE , which was published in ORG of DATE , ORG noted that , in the light of the principles it had established in its judgment of DATE , the aforementioned provision did not allow headscarves to be worn in institutions of higher education on religious grounds and so was consistent with the LAW . It stated , inter alia :

“ ... the expression ‘ laws in CARDINAL refers first and foremost to the LAW ... In institutions of higher education , it is contrary to the principles of secularism and equality for the neck and hair to be covered with a veil or headscarf on grounds of religious conviction . In these circumstances , the freedom of dress which the impugned provision permits in institutions of higher education ‘ does not concern dress of a religious nature or the act of covering one ’s neck and hair with a veil and headscarf’ ... The freedom afforded by this provision [ transitional section CARDINAL ] is conditional on its not being contrary to ‘ the laws in CARDINAL . The judgment [ of DATE ] of ORG establishes that covering one ’s neck and hair with the headscarf is first and foremost contrary to LAW . Consequently , the condition set out in the aforementioned section requiring [ choice of ] dress not to contravene the laws in force removes from the scope of freedom of dress the act of ‘ covering one ’s neck and hair with the headscarf’ ... ”

CARDINAL . For DATE the place of the NORP headscarf in ORG education has been the subject of debate across LOC . In most NORP countries , the debate has focused mainly on primary and secondary schools . However , in GPE , GPE and GPE it has concerned not just the question of individual liberty , but also the political meaning of the NORP headscarf . These are the only member GPE to have introduced regulations on wearing the NORP headscarf in universities .

CARDINAL . In GPE , where secularism is regarded as CARDINAL of the cornerstones of NORP values , legislation was passed on DATE regulating , in accordance with the principle of secularism , the wearing of signs or dress manifesting a religious affiliation in ORG primary and secondary schools . The legislation inserted a new LAW in LAW which provides : “ In ORG primary and secondary schools , the wearing of signs or dress by which pupils overtly manifest a religious affiliation is prohibited . The school rules shall state that the institution of disciplinary proceedings shall be preceded by dialogue with the pupil . ”

The Act applies to all ORG schools and educational institutions , including post - baccalaureate courses ( preparatory classes for entrance to the grandes écoles and vocational training courses ) . It does not apply to ORG universities . In addition , as a circular of CARDINAL DATE makes clear , it only concerns “ ... signs , such as the NORP headscarf , however named , the kippa or a cross that is manifestly oversized , which make the wearer ’s religious affiliation immediately identifiable ” .

CARDINAL . In GPE there is no general ban on wearing religious signs at school . However , they may do so only if human rights , the reputation of others , national security , public order , and public health and morals are protected and internal rules complied with . Further , teachers must not permit religious or philosophical proselytism under their authority or the organisation of political militancy by or on behalf of pupils . The decree stipulates that restrictions may be imposed by school rules . On DATE ORG issued a decree intended to institute equality of treatment . In ORG , there is no uniform policy among schools on whether to allow religious or philosophical signs to be worn . Some do , others do not . When pupils are permitted to wear such signs , restrictions may be imposed on grounds of hygiene or safety .
